awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Computational Approaches for Life Cycle Inventory Database Development
awd_abstract_narration:
1554349 (Xu)

This research aims to advance the current practice of developing Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) databases into a faster, less expensive process that still generates reliable LCI data. The research will (1) create a framework for modeling and analyzing LCI networks, (2) develop computational models for estimating missing LCI data, and (3) apply these models to evaluate LCI data quality and predict LCI data for emerging technologies. The education plan will (1) engage a diverse group of LCA practitioners during the course of the project, (2) deliver open source software add-ons for LCA practitioners to easily use the computational models developed in the proposed research, (3) develop an education theory grounded curriculum module incorporating research outcomes for broader dissemination, and (4) train undergraduate and graduate students with diverse background in STEM fields by engaging them in the research program and other education activities. 

This research will develop computational approaches for estimating missing data in Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) databases based solely on limited known data, without relying on time-consuming, expensive empirical data collection. The approach transfers the latest knowledge from network science to LCI database development. An LCI database represents the interdependence of unit processes and environmental interventions. The ensemble of such interdependence characterizes the structure of the underlying technology network (or LCI network). If sufficient enough, observed LCI data, although limited, can be used to extract structural features of the underlying LCI network. Such structural features, in turn, can be used to predict the structure of the unknown area of the LCI network, which is equivalent to estimating the unknown data in the LCI database. This research will first create a framework for modeling and analyzing LCI networks. This framework will then be used to develop and validate a variety of link prediction models to estimate missing data for LCI databases. Finally the validated link prediction models will be used to evaluate LCI data quality and predict LCI data for emerging technologies for testbed databases selected in consultation with stakeholders.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Life cycle assessment (LCA) measures the environmental impacts of a product in its whole life cycle from resource extraction through disposal. Increasingly, LCA has become an important element in environmental policy and voluntary actions around the world. A good LCA study relies on the availability and quality of life cycle inventory (LCI) data which measure the inputs of energy/resources and outputs of emissions/waste for each unit process of a product’s life cycle and the life cycle impact assessment (LCIA) data which evaluates the potential environmental impacts stemming from the elementary flows (environmental resources and releases) obtained in the LCI. Collecting empirical data to compile a high-quality LCI and LCIA can be time-consuming and expensive. In this project, we plan to develop an integrated research and education program to transform this time-consuming, expensive practice of creating LCA data into a faster, less expensive process that still generates reliable data.

 

First, we proposed a new computational approach to estimate missing LCI (i.e., unit process) data solely relying on limited known data based on a similarity-based link prediction method. The intuition is that similar processes in a unit process network tend to have similar material/energy inputs and waste/emission outputs. We used the ecoinvent 3.1 unit process data sets to test our method. The results show that missing data can be accurately estimated when less than 5% of data are missing in one process. The estimation performance decreases as the percentage of missing data increases.

 

Second, based on the results from the first task, we further developed a more flexible machine learning model to estimate missing unit process data as a complement to our previous method when more than 5% of the data are missing. In particular, we adopted a decision tree-based supervised learning approach on the same dataset (ecoinvent 3.1) to characterize the relationship between the known information (i.e., flows) and the missing one. The basic framework of our method can be divided into two steps. The first is a classification model to identify whether an elementary or intermediate flow exists in a certain unit process (whether a process uses a specific input or generates a particular output). Then, for those identified nonzero flows (existence), a regression model is constructed to estimate their numeric values. The results show that the model can still work when less than 50% of the data is missing.

 

Third, we developed machine learning models to estimate missing characterization factors data used in LCIA. Specifically, we constructed a random forest model to estimate the ecotoxicity hazardous concentrations 50% (HC50) in USEtox (version 2.11) to calculate characterization factors for chemicals based on their physical-chemical properties and the classification of their mode of action. The model is tested by ten randomly selected test sets that are not used for training.

 

Fourth, we also developed an artificial neural network model to predict chemical ecotoxicity (HC50). Specifically, to reduce the manual tuning effort on optimal network architecture, a genetic algorithm is investigated to automatically search and configure the network architecture. The physicochemical properties and their chemical descriptors are used to train and validate the model. Genetic algorithms which mimic the biological evolutionary process along generations are used to find the most appropriate neural network design. In each generation, we selected the fittest parameter combinations to reproduce offspring in the next generation. After a few generations, the most competent parameter combinations are found.

 

Lastly, we developed a machine learning-augmented method to improve the accuracy of the prediction of input-output (IO) tables as an extension of our LCA studies. The model is constructed by combining the RAS method with a deep neural network (DNN) model, in which the RAS method provides a baseline prediction and the DNN model makes further improvements in the areas where RAS tended to have poor performance. Our results based on the US summary-level tables showed that the DNN model can significantly improve the performance in those areas in IO tables for short-term prediction (one year) where RAS alone has poor performance. For long-term prediction (5 years), the improvements are even more significant.

 

This project advance the science and engineering of LCA data compilation by developing a computational framework for estimating missing LCI and LCIA data solely based on limited known LCI data, without relying on additional empirical data and contributes to other fields such as data science by providing new developments and case studies. Three students and one postdoctoral fellow have been trained and provided professional development opportunities through this project. The results of this project can potentially provide effective decision support for policymakers to make policies, environmental impact management, direct chemical management, and technology development.

 


Last Modified: 05/24/2022
Modified by: Ming Xu
por.por_txt_cntn:
Life cycle assessment (LCA) measures the environmental impacts of a product in its whole life cycle from resource extraction through disposal. Increasingly, LCA has become an important element in environmental policy and voluntary actions around the world. A good LCA study relies on the availability and quality of life cycle inventory (LCI) data which measure the inputs of energy/resources and outputs of emissions/waste for each unit process of a product’s life cycle and the life cycle impact assessment (LCIA) data which evaluates the potential environmental impacts stemming from the elementary flows (environmental resources and releases) obtained in the LCI. Collecting empirical data to compile a high-quality LCI and LCIA can be time-consuming and expensive. In this project, we plan to develop an integrated research and education program to transform this time-consuming, expensive practice of creating LCA data into a faster, less expensive process that still generates reliable data.

Our results based on the US summary-level tables showed that the DNN model can significantly improve the performance in those areas in IO tables for short-term prediction (one year) where RAS alone has poor performance. Three students and one postdoctoral fellow have been trained and provided professional development opportunities through this project. The results of this project can potentially provide effective decision support for policymakers to make policies, environmental impact management, direct chemical management, and technology development.
